str2: Of Hebrew origin; Jesus, the name of our Lord and two other Israelites.

parse: Verb - Imperfect Indicative Active - 3rd Person Singular
str2: To lead or carry about (or around), go about, traverse. From peri and ago; to take around; reflexively, to walk around.
All, the whole, every kind of. Including all the forms of declension; apparently a primary word; all, any, every, the whole.
The, the definite article. Including the feminine he, and the neuter to in all their inflections; the definite article; the.
A city, the inhabitants of a city. Probably from the same as polemos, or perhaps from polus; a town.
And, even, also, namely.
A village, country town. From keimai; a hamlet.

parse: Verb - Present Participle Active - Nominative Masculine Singular
str2: To teach, direct, admonish. A prolonged form of a primary verb dao; to teach.
In, on, among. A primary preposition denoting position, and instrumentality, i.e. A relation of rest; 'in, ' at, on, by, etc.

parse: Personal / Possessive Pronoun - Genitive Masculine 3rd Person Plural
str2: He, she, it, they, them, same. From the particle au; the reflexive pronoun self, used of the third person, and of the other persons.
From sunago; an assemblage of persons; specially, a Jewish 'synagogue'; by analogy, a Christian church.

parse: Verb - Present Participle Active - Nominative Masculine Singular
str2: To proclaim, herald, preach. Of uncertain affinity; to herald, especially divine truth.
The, the definite article. Including the feminine he, and the neuter to in all their inflections; the definite article; the.
From the same as euaggelizo; a good message, i.e. The gospel.
The, the definite article. Including the feminine he, and the neuter to in all their inflections; the definite article; the.
From basileus; properly, royalty, i.e. rule, or a realm.
And, even, also, namely.

parse: Verb - Present Participle Active - Nominative Masculine Singular
str2: From the same as therapon; to wait upon menially, i.e. to adore, or to relieve.
All, the whole, every kind of. Including all the forms of declension; apparently a primary word; all, any, every, the whole.
A disease, malady, sickness. Of uncertain affinity; a malady.
And, even, also, namely.
Weakness, illness, sickness. From malakos; softness, i.e. Enervation.
